name: Dwarven Thug Lord (Rogue 13 / Assassin 1 / Dwarven Defender 26)
author: Orion

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
Dwarven Thug Lord


The concept is pretty simple.

Knock em down and kill em. And be tanky enough to survive doing it.

Two handed weapon for added strength damage, and added sneak attack (up to 8d6).

Dwarven defender to access proficiencies galore, damage reduction (up to 18/-), bonus feats and huge HP boosts, 550hp without trying

Rogue for improved evasion and epic skill focus (I chose discipline, but listen might be another good choice) or Opportunist for more sneak damage (not that you need more)

Assassin 1 level for value 1d6 sneak attack and skill dumps in UMD/tumble.

Made a Greataxe version who gets added epic energy resistance to fire and acid and an AB of 43, and a Dev Crit version wielding a greatsword with an AB of 42, who loses two strength, these energy resistances and improved knockdown.

What do you think?

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
The Dev Crit version is the stronger one, doesn't matter if it has lower AB & no (I)KD.

But, I have to say that the most "complete build", is the first one.
Take Crippling strike with it, btw, on the first flurry, your opponent is already -4Str down & then becomes worse.

I like them Orion, offensive but with many defensive properties, the "balance" is strong with this one.

posts.author: gkorjax
posts.content: I love crippling strike.  It is hard to squeeze in often, but wow do I love to play builds with it.

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
Good call on Crippling Strike!

I have just read about it in the NWN Wiki and it seems very strong!

Thankfully it is pretty simple to fit it in, swap ESF: Discipline for it. 

Not sure whether it should be before or after Improved Evasion though, what do you think?

Thank you for the comments. Have learnt a bit about the Rogue class now!

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
In this case, it should be after, & the reason is that you don't have enough attacks (and neither twf)  to take advantage of it, yet.
When you have 4+ attacks/round it should always be your first choice.
